child.pub-comments: For more information about Kanite, see McCarthy 1965.

Population: 84,000 "…in Kamano-Yagaria the dialects at the extreme ends of the [dialect] chains clearly constitute different languages, but the dialects in the middle show about equal relationship to both ends of the chain. Hence there is no non-arbitrary way to draw a line separating the two languages (see Wurm and Laycock 1961 for further discussion of this problem)" (Foley 1986:237).

child.publications: Foley, William A. 1986. The Papuan Language of New Guinea. London: Cambridge University Press.
child.pub-comments: Population: 9,000 For more information about Gende, see Aufenanger 1952 and the dissertation by R. Brandson

child.publications: Foley, William A. 1986. The Papuan Language of New Guinea. London: Cambridge University Press.
child.pub-comments: Population: 15,000 For more information about BenaBena, see Young 1971.

child.publications: Foley, William A. 1986. The Papuan Language of New Guinea. London: Cambridge University Press.
child.pub-comments: Population: 23,000 For more information about Gahuku, see Deibler 1976; for more information about Asaro, see Strange 1965 and 1973.

child.publications: Foley, William A. 1986. The Papuan Language of New Guinea. London: Cambridge University Press.

child.pub-comments: Population: 13,000 For more information about Fore, see Scott 1978 and 1980.

child.publications: Foley, William A. 1986. The Papuan Language of New Guinea. London: Cambridge University Press.
child.pub-comments: Population: 16,000 For more information about Siane, see James (ms) and Haiman 1980.

"Dialect differentiation in a number of these languages, especially the larger ones, is very great, and this creates problems in classification. The problem is essentially caused by dialect chain" (Foley 1986:236). For comparative material about this family, see Scott 1978.

child.publications: Foley, William A. 1986. The Papuan Language of New Guinea. London: Cambridge University Press.

child.geography: spoken in the Eastern Highlands Province around Kainantu

child.pub-comments: "Dialect differentiation in all [Kainantu languages] but Awa is quite great, and some of these dialects may constitute separate languages" (Foley 1986:236). Kainantu is a well-studied language: for more information about the Kainantu languages, see McKaughan 1973; for a dictionary of Awa, see Loving and Loving 1975.

child.publications: Foley, William A. 1986. The Papuan Language of New Guinea. London: Cambridge University Press.

child.geography: spoken in the central highlands of Irian Jaya, from Wissel Lakes eastward to the border of the Dani family

child.pub-comments: Population: 12,000 For more information about Moni, see Larson and Larson 1958.

child.publications: Foley, William A. 1986. The Papuan Language of New Guinea. London: Cambridge University Press.

child.pub-comments: Population: around 90,000 speakers "For this family published materials are only available for Ekagi and Moni" (Foley 1986:240). For comparative work in this family, see Larson and Larson 1972.

child.geography: spoken around the valley of the Balim River in the central highlands of Irian Jaya

child.pub-comments: For more information about Lower Grand Valley Dani, see Bromley 1981.

Population: 75,000 "Both Grand Valley and Western Dani have a number of quite divergent dialects" (Foley 1986:240). For more information about Grand Valley Dani, see Bromley 1961, Stap 1966 and Fahner 1979.

child.pub-comments: Population: 100,000 "Both Grand Valley and Western Dani have a number of quite divergent dialects" (Foley 1986:240). For more information about Western Dani, see Bromley 1961.

child.pub-comments: Population: 6,350 Kâte and Selepet are the two of best known Papuan languages. For more information about Selepet, see McElhanon 1967b, 1970a, 1970b, 1970c, 1970d, 1972, and McElhanon and McElhanon 1970.

child.pub-comments: Population: 6,130 "Kâte has been used as a lingua franca by the Luthern Mission" (Foley 1986: 244). Kâte and Selepet are the two of best known Papuan languages. For more information about Kâte, see Pilhofer 1928, 1929, and 1933, Schneuker 1962, Keysser 123, Flierl and Strauss 1977.

child.publications: Foley, William A. 1986. The Papuan Language of New Guinea. London: Cambridge University Press.
Foley, William A. 1986. The Papuan Language of New Guinea. London: Cambridge University Press.
Foley, William A. 1986. The Papuan Language of New Guinea. London: Cambridge University Press.

child.pub-comments: "Comparative work in this family is the labour of McElhanon; publications include McElhanon 1967a; 1970e; 1971; 1973; 1975" (Foley 1986:244). While Kâte and Selepet are well known and well-documented, other languages of this family are more poorly documented (Foley 1986:244).

root.pub-comments: "Population growth in recent years in certain areas of New Guinea has been on the order of three per cent per year, suggesting that, for some languages discussed below, the population of speakers at present (1985) may be up to thirty per cent higher than the figure given" (Foley 1986:232).
